code: @Manual{,   title = {autovi: Auto visual inference with computer vision models},   author = {Weihao Li},   year = {2023},   note = {https://tengmcing.github.io/autovi/, https://github.com/TengMCing/autovi/}, }

what: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
title: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
text: goal autovi provide tools conducting auto visual inference.

title: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
text: can install development version autovi like :
code: remotes::install_github("TengMCing/autovi")

title: Auto visual inference with computer vision models
code: library(tidyverse) # Load keras model for predicting visual signal strength. keras_mod <- keras::load_model_tf(here::here("temp_model/32"))  # To illustrate the use of this package we define the data generating process for data simulation.  dgp_mod <- visage::poly_model(x = visage::rand_uniform(-1, 1), sigma = 1)  # Simulate 300 observations. this_dat <- dgp_mod$gen(300)  # Get the fitted model (`lm`) on the simulated data. this_mod <- dgp_mod$fit(this_dat) # Init an instance. my_vi <- autovi::auto_vi(fitted_mod = this_mod,                          keras_mod = keras_mod,                          node_index = 1L)  # Have a look at the target residual plot. my_vi$plot_resid() # Predict the visual signal strength for the target residual plot. my_vi$plot_resid() %>%   my_vi$vss() #> [1] 4.368939 # Run an automatic check for the fitted model. # We simulate 100 null data sets and 1000 bootstrapped data sets,  # and let the keras model predict the visual signal strength  # for each residual plot.  my_vi$check(boot_draws = 1000L, null_draws = 100L, correction = TRUE)  # Print the object to get a summary of the result. my_vi #>  #> ── <AUTO_VI object> #> Status: #>  - Fitted model: lm #>  - Keras model: (None, 32, 32, 3) -> (None, 1) #>     - Output node index: 1 #>  - Result: #>     - Observed visual signal strength: 4.369 (p-value = 0) #>     - Null visual signal strength: [100 draws] #>        - Mean: 0.06388 #>        - Quantiles:  #>           ╔═════════════════════════════════════════════════╗ #>           ║   25%    50%    75%    80%    90%    95%    99% ║ #>           ║0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.0000 0.1828 0.3287 1.3006 ║ #>           ╚═════════════════════════════════════════════════╝ #>     - Bootstrapped visual signal strength: [300000 draws] #>        - Mean: 4.381 (p-value = 0) #>        - Quantiles:  #>           ╔══════════════════════════════════════════╗ #>           ║  25%   50%   75%   80%   90%   95%   99% ║ #>           ║4.229 4.394 4.546 4.585 4.685 4.765 4.931 ║ #>           ╚══════════════════════════════════════════╝ #>     - Likelihood ratio: 1.648 (boot) / 0 (null) = Inf # Draw a summary plot. my_vi$summary_plot()

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..
text: function called instance built. User input stored environment.

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..
code: AUTO_VI$..init..(fitted_mod, keras_mod = NULL, dat = NULL, node_index = 1L)

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..
text: fitted_mod Model. model object, e.g. lm. keras_mod Keras model. trained computer vision model. dat Data frame. data used fit model. node_index Integer. index indicating node output layer contains visual signal strength. particularly useful keras model one output nodes.

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..
text: Return object .

title: Initialization method — AUTO_VI$..init..
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) my_vi #>  #> ── <AUTO_VI object> #> Status: #>  - Fitted model: lm #>  - Keras model: UNKNOWN #>     - Output node index: 1 #>  - Result: UNKNOWN

what: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
text: function bootstrap data refits model, predicts visual signal strength bootstrapped residual plots.

title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
code: AUTO_VI$boot_vss(   draws = 100L,   fitted_mod = self$fitted_mod,   keras_mod = self$keras_mod,   correction = FALSE,   jitter = FALSE,   factor = 1L,   dat = self$get_dat(),   node_index = 1L,   keep_boot_dat = FALSE,   keep_boot_plot = FALSE )

title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
text: draws Integer. Number simulation draws. fitted_mod Model. model object, e.g. lm. keras_mod Keras model. trained computer vision model. correction Boolean. Correction bootstrapped visual signal strength due reduction unique data points null plots. jitter Boolean. Whether use jitter() generate bootstrapped data instead sampling original data replacement. factor Numeric. See also jitter(). dat Data frame. data used fit model. See also AUTO_VI$get_dat(). node_index Integer. index indicating node output layer contains visual signal strength. particularly useful keras model one output nodes. keep_boot_dat Boolean. Whether keep bootstrapped data. keep_boot_plot Boolean. Whether keep bootstrapped plots.

title: Predict visual signal strength for bootstrapped residual plots — AUTO_VI$boot_vss
text: tibble 1 3 columns depending argument keep_boot_dat keep_boot_plot.

what: Conduct a auto visual inference check with a computer vision model — AUTO_VI$check
title: Conduct a auto visual inference check with a computer vision model — AUTO_VI$check
text: function conducts visual inference check computer vision model.

title: Conduct a auto visual inference check with a computer vision model — AUTO_VI$check
code: AUTO_VI$check(   null_draws = 100L,   boot_draws = 100L,   fitted_mod = self$fitted_mod,   keras_mod = self$keras_mod,   method = self$rotate_resid,   correction = FALSE,   jitter = FALSE,   factor = 1L,   dat = self$get_dat(),   node_index = self$node_index,   keep_dat = FALSE,   keep_plot = FALSE )

title: Conduct a auto visual inference check with a computer vision model — AUTO_VI$check
text: null_draws Integer. Number simulation draws AUTO_VI$null_vss(). boot_draws Integer. Number simulation draws AUTO_VI$boot_vss(). fitted_mod Model. model object, e.g. lm. keras_mod Keras model. trained computer vision model. method Function. method simulate residuals null hypothesis distribution. lm, recommended method residual rotation AUTO_VI$rotate_resid(). correction Boolean. Correction bootstrapped visual signal strength due reduction unique data points null plots. jitter Boolean. Whether use jitter() generate bootstrapped data instead sampling original data replacement. factor Numeric. See also jitter(). dat Data frame. data used fit model. See also AUTO_VI$get_dat(). node_index Integer. index indicating node output layer contains visual signal strength. particularly useful keras model one output nodes. keep_dat Boolean. Whether keep simulated data. keep_plot Boolean. Whether keep simulated plots.

text: draws Integer. Number simulation draws. fitted_mod Model. model object, e.g. lm. keras_mod Keras model. trained computer vision model. method Function. method simulate residuals null hypothesis distribution. lm, recommended method residual rotation AUTO_VI$rotate_resid(). node_index Integer. index indicating node output layer contains visual signal strength. particularly useful keras model one output nodes. keep_null_dat Boolean. Whether keep simulated null data. keep_null_plot Boolean. Whether keep simulated null plots.

what: Draw a standard residual plot — AUTO_VI$plot_resid
title: Draw a standard residual plot — AUTO_VI$plot_resid
text: function draws standard residual plot.

title: Draw a standard residual plot — AUTO_VI$plot_resid
code: AUTO_VI$plot_resid(   dat = self$get_fitted_and_resid(),   theme = ggplot2::theme_light(base_size = 11/5),   alpha = 1,   size = 0.5,   stroke = 0.5,   remove_axis = TRUE,   remove_legend = TRUE,   remove_grid_line = TRUE,   add_zero_line = TRUE )

title: Draw a standard residual plot — AUTO_VI$plot_resid
text: dat Data frame. data frame containing variables .resid .fitted. See also AUTO_VI$get_fitted_and_resid(). theme ggtheme. ggplot theme object. See also ggplot2::theme_light(). alpha Numeric. Alpha dot. Value 0 1. size Numeric. Size dot. Value 0 1. stroke Numeric. Stroke dot. Value 0 1. remove_axis Boolean. Whether remove axis. remove_legend Boolean. Whether remove legend. remove_grid_line Boolean. Whether remove grid lines. add_zero_line Boolean. Whether add zero horizontal line.

title: Draw a standard residual plot — AUTO_VI$plot_resid
text: ggplot.

title: Draw a standard residual plot — AUTO_VI$plot_resid
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) my_vi$plot_resid()

title: Remove a plot — AUTO_VI$remove_plot
text: Return object .

title: Remove a plot — AUTO_VI$remove_plot
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) temp_path <- my_vi$save_plot(my_vi$plot_resid()) my_vi$remove_plot(temp_path) file.exists(temp_path) #> [1] FALSE

what: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
title: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
text: function gets rotated residuals fitted linear model. rotated residuals generated first regressing random noises original regressors, multiply obtained residuals original RSS divided current RSS. results rotated residuals.

title: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
code: AUTO_VI$rotate_resid(fitted_mod = self$fitted_mod)

title: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
text: fitted_mod lm. linear model object.

title: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
text: tibble two columns .fitted .resid.

title: Get rotated residuals from a fitted linear model — AUTO_VI$rotate_resid
code: my_vi <- auto_vi(fitted_mod = lm(speed ~ dist, data = cars)) rotated_resid <- my_vi$rotate_resid() my_vi$plot_resid(rotated_resid)
